summary.value:
Primary alcohols can be oxidised to form aldehydes and carboxylic acids whilst secondary alcohols can be oxidised to form ketones. Whether an aldehyde or carboxylic acid is formed from a primary alcohol depends on the conditions used. Oxidation of alcohols is typically carried out using a mixture of an oxidising agent such as potassium dichromate (VI) and dilute sulfuric acid. The oxidising agent turns from orange to green when oxidation occurs.

Aldehydes are further oxidised to carboxylic acids and so adding small quantities of the oxidising agent and carrying out the oxidation using distillation apparatus reduces the likelihood of the aldehyde being further oxidised to a carboxylic acid. Heating the mixture under reflux encourages the formation of the carboxylic acid.
